BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING)
坊っちゃん
by Mr. Kin-nosuke Natsume, trans. by Yasotaro Morri
夏目漱石



CHAPTER I
一
Because of an hereditary recklessness, I have been playing always a losing game since my childhood.
親譲（おやゆず）りの無鉄砲（むてっぽう）で小供の時から損ばかりしている。
During my grammar school days, I was once laid up for about a week by jumping from the second story of the school building.
小学校に居る時分学校の二階から飛び降りて一週間ほど腰（こし）を抜（ぬ）かした事がある。
Some may ask why I committed such a rash act.
なぜそんな無闇（むやみ）をしたと聞く人があるかも知れぬ。
There was no particular reason for doing such a thing
別段深い理由でもない。
except I happened to be looking out into the yard from the second floor of the newly-built school house, when one of my classmates, joking, shouted at me; "Say, you big bluff, I'll bet you can't jump down from there! O, you chicken-heart, ha, ha!"
新築の二階から首を出していたら、同級生の一人が冗談（じょうだん）に、いくら威張（いば）っても、そこから飛び降りる事は出来まい。 弱虫やーい。 と囃（はや）したからである。
So I jumped down. The janitor of the school had to carry me home on his back, and when my father saw me, he yelled derisively, "What a fellow you are to go and get your bones dislocated by jumping only from a second story!"
小使（こづかい）に負ぶさって帰って来た時、おやじが大きな眼（め）をして二階ぐらいから飛び降りて腰を抜かす奴（やつ）があるかと云（い）ったから、
"I'll see I don't get dislocated next time,"
この次は抜かさずに飛んで見せます
I answered.
と答えた。
One of my relatives once presented me with a pen-knife.
親類のものから西洋製のナイフを貰（もら）って
I was showing it to my friends, reflecting its pretty blades against the rays of the sun, when one of them chimed in that the blades gleamed all right, but seemed rather dull for cutting with.
奇麗（きれい）な刃（は）を日に翳（かざ）して、友達（ともだち）に見せていたら、一人が光る事は光るが切れそうもないと云った。
"Rather dull? See if they don't cut!" I retorted.
切れぬ事があるか、何でも切ってみせると受け合った。
"Cut your finger, then," he challenged.
そんなら君の指を切ってみろと注文したから、
And with "Finger nothing! Here goes!" I cut my thumb slant-wise.
何だ指ぐらいこの通りだと右の手の親指の甲（こう）をはすに切り込（こ）んだ。
Fortunately the knife was small and the bone of the thumb hard enough, so the thumb is still there,
幸（さいわい）ナイフが小さいのと、親指の骨が堅（かた）かったので、今だに親指は手に付いている。
but the scar will be there until my death.
しかし創痕（きずあと）は死ぬまで消えぬ。
About twenty steps to the east edge of our garden, there was a moderate-sized vegetable yard, rising toward the south, and in the centre of which stood a chestnut tree
庭を東へ二十歩に行き尽（つく）すと、南上がりにいささかばかりの菜園があって、真中（まんなか）に栗（くり）の木が一本立っている。
which was dearer to me than life.
これは命より大事な栗だ。
In the season when the chestnuts were ripe, I used to slip out of the house from the back door early in the morning to pick up the chestnuts which had fallen during the night, and eat them at the school.
実の熟する時分は起き抜けに背戸（せど）を出て落ちた奴を拾ってきて、学校で食う。
On the west side of the vegetable yard was the adjoining garden of a pawn shop called Yamashiro-ya.
菜園の西側が山城屋（やましろや）という質屋の庭続きで、
This shopkeeper's son was a boy about 13 or 14 years old named Kantaro.
この質屋に勘太郎（かんたろう）という十三四の倅（せがれ）が居た。
Kantaro was, it happens, a mollycoddle.
勘太郎は無論弱虫である。
Nevertheless he had the temerity to come over the fence to our yard and steal my chestnuts.
弱虫の癖（くせ）に四つ目垣を乗りこえて、栗を盗（ぬす）みにくる。
One certain evening I hid myself behind a folding-gate of the fence and caught him in the act.
ある日の夕方折戸（おりど）の蔭（かげ）に隠（かく）れて、とうとう勘太郎を捕（つら）まえてやった。
Having his retreat cut off he grappled with me in desperation.
その時勘太郎は逃（に）げ路（みち）を失って、一生懸命（いっしょうけんめい）に飛びかかってきた。
He was about two years older than I,
向（むこ）うは二つばかり年上である。
and, though weak-kneed, was physically the stronger.
弱虫だが力は強い。
While I wallopped him, he pushed his head against my breast and by chance it slipped inside my sleeve.
鉢（はち）の開いた頭を、こっちの胸へ宛（あ）ててぐいぐい押（お）した拍子（ひょうし）に、勘太郎の頭がすべって、おれの袷（あわせ）の袖（そで）の中にはいった。
As this hindered the free action of my arm, I tried to shake him loose, though, his head dangled the further inside,
邪魔（じゃま）になって手が使えぬから、無暗に手を振（ふ）ったら、袖の中にある勘太郎の頭が、右左へぐらぐら靡（なび）いた。
and being no longer able to stand the stifling combat, he bit my bare arm.
しまいに苦しがって袖の中から、おれの二の腕（うで）へ食い付いた。
It was painful.
痛かったから
I held him fast against the fence, and by a dexterous foot twist sent him down flat on his back.
勘太郎を垣根へ押しつけておいて、足搦（あしがら）をかけて向うへ倒（たお）してやった。
Kantaro broke the fence and as the ground belonging to Yamashiro-ya was about six feet lower than the vegetable yard, he fell headlong to his own territory with a thud.
山城屋の地面は菜園より六尺がた低い。 勘太郎は四つ目垣を半分崩（くず）して、自分の領分へ真逆様（まっさかさま）に落ちて、ぐうと云った。
As he rolled off he tore away the sleeve in which his head had been enwrapped, and my arm recovered a sudden freedom of movement.
勘太郎が落ちるときに、おれの袷の片袖がもげて、急に手が自由になった。
That night when my mother went to Yamashiro-ya to apologize, she brought back that sleeve.
その晩母が山城屋に詫（わ）びに行ったついでに袷の片袖も取り返して来た。
Besides the above, I did many other mischiefs.
この外いたずらは大分やった。
With Kaneko of a carpenter shop and Kaku of a fishmarket, I once ruined a carrot patch of one Mosaku.
大工の兼公（かねこう）と肴屋（さかなや）の角（かく）をつれて、茂作（もさく）の人参畠（にんじんばたけ）をあらした事がある。
The sprouts were just shooting out and the patch was covered with straws to ensure their even healthy growth.
人参の芽が出揃（でそろ）わぬ処（ところ）へ藁（わら）が一面に敷（し）いてあったから、
Upon this straw-covered patch, we three wrestled for fully half a day, and consequently thoroughly smashed all the sprouts.
その上で三人が半日相撲（すもう）をとりつづけに取ったら、人参がみんな踏（ふ）みつぶされてしまった。
Also I once filled up a well which watered some rice fields owned by one Furukawa, and he followed me with kicks.
古川（ふるかわ）の持っている田圃（たんぼ）の井戸（いど）を埋（う）めて尻（しり）を持ち込まれた事もある。
The well was so devised that from a large bamboo pole, sunk deep into the ground, the water issued and irrigated the rice fields.
太い孟宗（もうそう）の節を抜いて、深く埋めた中から水が湧（わ）き出て、そこいらの稲（いね）にみずがかかる仕掛（しかけ）であった。
Ignorant of the mechanical side of this irrigating method at that time, I stuffed the bamboo pole with stones and sticks, and satisfied that no more water came up, I returned home and was eating supper when Furukawa, fiery red with anger, burst into our house with howling protests.
その時分はどんな仕掛か知らぬから、石や棒（ぼう）ちぎれをぎゅうぎゅう井戸の中へ挿（さ）し込んで、水が出なくなったのを見届けて、うちへ帰って飯を食っていたら、古川が真赤（まっか）になって怒鳴（どな）り込んで来た。
I believe the affair was settled on our paying for the damage.
たしか罰金（ばっきん）を出して済んだようである。
Father did not like me in the least,
おやじはちっともおれを可愛（かわい）がってくれなかった。
and mother always sided with my big brother.
母は兄ばかり贔屓（ひいき）にしていた。
This brother's face was palish white, and he had a fondness for taking the part of an actress at the theatre.
この兄はやに色が白くって、芝居（しばい）の真似（まね）をして女形（おんながた）になるのが好きだった。
"This fellow will never amount to much," father used to remark when he saw me.
おれを見る度にこいつはどうせ碌（ろく）なものにはならないと、おやじが云った。
"He's so reckless that I worry about his future, " I often heard mother say of me.
乱暴で乱暴で行く先が案じられると母が云った。
Exactly; I have never amounted to much.
なるほど碌なものにはならない。
I am just as you see me;
ご覧の通りの始末である。
no wonder my future used to cause anxiety to my mother.
行く先が案じられたのも無理はない。
I am living without becoming but a jailbird.
ただ懲役（ちょうえき）に行かないで生きているばかりである。
Two or three days previous to my mother's death, I took it into my head to turn a somersault in the kitchen, and painfully hit my ribs against the corner of the stove.
母が病気で死ぬ二三日（にさんち）前台所で宙返りをしてへっついの角で肋骨（あばらぼね）を撲（う）って大いに痛かった。
Mother was very angry at this and told me not to show my face again, so I went to a relative to stay with.
母が大層怒（おこ）って、お前のようなものの顔は見たくないと云うから、親類へ泊（とま）りに行っていた。
While there, I received the news that my mother's illness had become very serious, and that after all efforts for her recovery, she was dead.
するととうとう死んだと云う報知（しらせ）が来た。
I came home thinking that I should have behaved better if I had known the conditions were so serious as that.
そう早く死ぬとは思わなかった。 そんな大病なら、もう少し大人（おとな）しくすればよかったと思って帰って来た。
Then that big brother of mine denounced me as wanting in filial piety, and that I had caused her untimely death.
そうしたら例の兄がおれを親不孝だ、おれのために、おっかさんが早く死んだんだと云った。
Mortified at this, I slapped his face, and thereupon received a sound scolding from father.
口惜（くや）しかったから、兄の横っ面を張って大変叱（しか）られた。
After the death of mother, I lived with father and brother.
母が死んでからは、おやじと兄と三人で暮（くら）していた。
Father did nothing, and always said "You're no good" to my face.
おやじは何にもせぬ男で、人の顔さえ見れば貴様は駄目（だめ）だ駄目だと口癖のように云っていた。
What he meant by "no good" I am yet to understand.
何が駄目なんだか今に分らない。
A funny dad he was.
妙（みょう）なおやじがあったもんだ。
My brother was to be seen studying English hard, saying that he was going to be a businessman.
兄は実業家になるとか云ってしきりに英語を勉強していた。
He was like a girl by nature, and so "sassy" that we two were never on good terms,
元来女のような性分で、ずるいから、仲がよくなかった。
and had to fight it out about once every ten days.
十日に一遍（いっぺん）ぐらいの割で喧嘩（けんか）をしていた。
When we played a chess game one day, he placed a chessman as a "waiter,"--a cowardly tactic this,--and had hearty laugh on me by seeing me in a fix.
ある時将棋（しょうぎ）をさしたら卑怯（ひきょう）な待駒（まちごま）をして、人が困ると嬉（うれ）しそうに冷やかした。
His manner was so trying that time that I banged a chessman on his forehead
あんまり腹が立ったから、手に在った飛車を眉間（みけん）へ擲（たた）きつけてやった。
which was injured a little bit and bled.
眉間が割れて少々血が出た。
He told all about this to father,
兄がおやじに言付（いつ）けた。
who said he would disinherit me.
おやじがおれを勘当（かんどう）すると言い出した。
Then I gave up myself for lost, and expected to be really disinherited.
その時はもう仕方がないと観念して先方の云う通り勘当されるつもりでいたら、
But our maid Kiyo, who had been with us for ten years or so, interceded on my behalf, and tearfully apologized for me, and by her appeal my father's wrath was softened.
十年来召し使っている清（きよ）という下女が、泣きながらおやじに詫（あや）まって、ようやくおやじの怒（いか）りが解けた。
I did not regard him, however, as one to be afraid of in any way,
それにもかかわらずあまりおやじを怖（こわ）いとは思わなかった。
but rather felt sorry for our Kiyo.
かえってこの清と云う下女に気の毒であった。
I had heard that Kiyo was of a decent, well-to-do family, but being driven to poverty at the time of the Restoration, had to work as a servant.
この下女はもと由緒（ゆいしょ）のあるものだったそうだが、瓦解（がかい）のときに零落（れいらく）して、つい奉公（ほうこう）までするようになったのだと聞いている。
So she was an old woman by this time.
だから婆（ばあ）さんである。
This old woman,--by what affinity, as the Buddhists say, I don't know,--loved me a great deal.
この婆さんがどういう因縁（いんえん）か、おれを非常に可愛がってくれた。
Strange, indeed!
不思議なものである。
She was almost blindly fond of me,--me, whom mother, became thoroughly disgusted with three days before her death; whom father considered a most aggravating proposition all the year round, and whom the neighbors cordially hated as the local bully among the youngsters.
母も死ぬ三日前に愛想（あいそ）をつかした ――おやじも年中持て余している ――町内では乱暴者の悪太郎と爪弾（つまはじ）きをする ――このおれを無暗に珍重（ちんちょう）してくれた。
I had long reconciled myself to the fact that my nature was far from being attractive to others, and so didn't mind if I were treated as a piece of wood;
おれは到底（とうてい）人に好かれる性（たち）でないとあきらめていたから、他人から木の端（はし）のように取り扱（あつか）われるのは何とも思わない、
so I thought it uncommon that Kiyo should pet me like that.
かえってこの清のようにちやほやしてくれるのを不審（ふしん）に考えた。
Sometimes in the kitchen, when there was nobody around, she would praise me saying that I was straightforward and of a good disposition.
清は時々台所で人の居ない時に 「あなたは真（ま）っ直（すぐ）でよいご気性だ」 と賞（ほ）める事が時々あった。
What she meant by that exactly, was not clear to me, however.
しかしおれには清の云う意味が分からなかった。
If I were of so good a nature as she said, I imagined those other than Kiyo should accord me a better treatment.
好（い）い気性なら清以外のものも、もう少し善くしてくれるだろうと思った。
So whenever Kiyo said to me anything of the kind, I used to answer that I did not like passing compliments.
清がこんな事を云う度におれはお世辞は嫌（きら）いだと答えるのが常であった。
Then she would remark; "That's the very reason I say you are of a good disposition,"
すると婆さんはそれだから好いご気性ですと云っては、
and would gaze at me with absorbing tenderness.
嬉しそうにおれの顔を眺（なが）めている。
She seemed to recreate me by her own imagination, and was proud of the fact.
自分の力でおれを製造して誇（ほこ）ってるように見える。
I felt even chilled through my marrow at her constant attention to me.
少々気味がわるかった。
After my mother was dead, Kiyo loved me still more.
母が死んでから清はいよいよおれを可愛がった。
In my simple reasoning, I wondered why she had taken such a fancy to me.
時々は小供心になぜあんなに可愛がるのかと不審に思った。
Sometimes I thought it quite futile on her part, that she had better quit that sort of thing,
つまらない、廃（よ）せばいいのにと思った。
which was bad for her.
気の毒だと思った。
But she loved me just the same.
それでも清は可愛がる。
Once in, a while she would buy, out of her own pocket, some cakes or sweetmeats for me.
折々は自分の小遣（こづか）いで金鍔（きんつば）や紅梅焼（こうばいやき）を買ってくれる。
When the night was cold, she would secretly buy some noodle powder, and bring all unawares hot noodle gruel to my bed;
寒い夜などはひそかに蕎麦粉（そばこ）を仕入れておいて、いつの間にか寝（ね）ている枕元（まくらもと）へ蕎麦湯を持って来てくれる。
or sometimes she would even buy a bowl of steaming noodles from the peddler.
時には鍋焼饂飩（なべやきうどん）さえ買ってくれた。
